Award.AwardTitle: Silicon-Based Porous Ceramics via Freeze-Casting Preceramic Polymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Capturing particulates from diesel engine exhausts, providing channels for gaseous transport in fuel cells, and retaining heat via insulation all rely on porous materials. Each of these applications requires porous networks with distinctive size, shape, roughness, and connectivity to control and ease the flow or filtering or insulating capabilities. Many energy-related applications also require materials (ceramics) that maintain strength and robustness to temperatures in excess of 1500 C (2732 F). Advanced ceramics produced from preceramic polymers surpass conventional materials for high-temperature applications. This project focuses on the use of preceramic polymers to create new high-temperature porous ceramics by freeze casting. The polymers are dissolved in organic solvents, that when frozen in a controlled manner and converted to a ceramic, produce directionally porous networks that are optimized for flow characteristics and mechanical integrity. By developing an understanding of the chemistry of these freeze-casting systems, creating versatile pore architectures is possible, thereby expanding the use of porous ceramics for environmental and energy needs. Students involved in this research are trained in state-of-the-art ceramic processing and characterization methods, as preparation for the technical workforce. As an added benefit, porous materials produced by these methods resemble those found in nature and offer striking images that afford opportunities for science education through art.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The use of preceramic polymers to create silicon- and boron-based ceramics provides a route to high-temperature creep- and chemically-resistant materials. Traditionally, large shrinkages accompany the conversion to ceramic by polymer pyrolysis often resulting in cracking. To deal with this issue, components are limited to thin fibers, plates, and foamed porous solids. This research builds on the foundation of ceramic processing from preceramic polymers, and extends their formability using directional freeze casting. Compared to other porous material-forming methods, directional freeze casting affords anisotropic continuous pores, whose size, shape and tortuosity can be tuned, and hence, opens new avenues for energy-related applications. To make freeze casting viable for preceramic polymers, it is necessary to develop a fundamental understanding of polymer-solvent pairs and crosslinking catalysts using spectroscopic measurements and real-time microscopic observation of phase separation and solidification. An added benefit of preceramic polymers is their ability to be functionalized using reactive additives and fugitive phases, resulting in more complex chemistries and hierarchical microstructures for greater functionality. These materials provide a new class of freeze-cast solids where their pore network characteristics are of particular interest; they are explored using synchrotron techniques and permeability experiments. Moreover, their mechanical properties, consisting of anisotropic pores and complex pore wall structures, are assessed with respect to conventional mechanics models for porous materials. The research seeds an international collaboration with Prof. Paolo Colombo (Universita di Padova, Italy), an internationally recognized expert in preceramic polymers and porous ceramics, and provides significant international training experiences for students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pores have long been regarded as undesirable in the search for the perfect ceramic. The deleterious role of pores on mechanical properties notwithstanding,porosity has now become important, even critical, in expanding the utility of ceramic materials.  In addition to lowering  density, pores have become the conduits for fuels and reaction products in fuel and electrolysis cells.  They serve as the size limiter in filtration, the source of high surface area for catalysts, and the path for cell growth in biomedical implants. Strategies for producing, understanding and controlling pore structures in oxide and carbide ceramics have been explored using a processing method known directional freeze casting of ceramic suspensions or solutions of preceramic polymers. Here, the solvent, upon freezing, pushes ceramic particles or preceramic polymers aside and serves as a sacrificial template for the pore network. 

The contributions from this work lie in three main areas of focus: pore shape or morphology to tailor pores for the desired functionality, mechanical robustness of porous solids, and hierarchical pore structures for multifunctionality. 

First, by addressing freeze-casting using underlying knowledge of thermodynamics, an unprecedented control over pore morphology results during the casting process. The enthalpy of fusion and melting temperature of the freezing fluid indicates whether the frozen crystal, and hence, the pore network will have characteristics of sponges, trees (dendrites), or layered decks of card. For example, Figure 1 displays four vastly different pore networks, all of a silicon oxycarbide ceramic, but produced with four different solvents used with the preceramic polymer. The isotropic or sponge-like pore structure might be useful for cell growth in biomedical implants, while the dendritic, tree-like structure has numerous branches for capture during filtration.

Second, one of the deficiencies of porous ceramics is their poor mechanical integrity. To undertake these challenges, composite strategies have been incorporated into the freeze-casting process. Reinforcements such as carbon nanotubes not only prove to significantly enhance the toughness and strength of the pore walls, the electrical conductivity increases by ten orders of magnitude with as little as 4% (by weight) nanotube additions. Larger reinforcements, such as whiskers, prove an added benefit. They become engulfed by the freezing solvent and result in whisker bridges across pore walls, providing added rigidity and strength, without compromising flow characteristics.

Finally, pores that are present over multiple length scales in a given solid, known as hierarchical pores, provide multifunctionality to materials. As one illustration, natural materials, such as wood, have open channels that are present over length scales that range from sub-micrometer to hundreds of micrometers, where each scale is associated with a unique function.  Large diameter vessels along the trunk of the tree allow easy transport of nutrients, while small diameter channels in the radial direction serve to store those nutrients without compromising mechanical stability. New freeze-casting methods were designed to provide similar pore hierarchy.  By undertaking a two-stage freeze casting, the porous body is re-infiltrated prior to ceramic conversion. The result, shown in Figure 2, demonstrates an oxycarbide ceramic with approximately 60 micrometer size pores, filled with a network pore channels one-third the size. Such structures might be used for filtration where the smaller pore openings would control the size of the substance captured, while the larger opening ensures that ?back pressure? is sufficiently low for continued operation. Such hierarchy can be extended to nanometer size pores, of interest in catalysis, as a result of collaborations with the Ari Force Research Laboratory.

Broader Impact.  A vital part of this program was the interchange of ideas among various collaborators who were experts in preceramic polymers, X-ray tomography, solidification theory, and flow through membranes, the latter with chemical engineers on the Caltech campus.  The grant allowed for students to visit the Universit? di Padova and the Friedrich-Alexander-Universit?t Erlangen-N?rnberg. Likewise, students from the collaborating universities spent time at Caltech. These visits were often planned in conjunction with international meetings, so that students could present their work in an international forum. The personal interactions were key to transferring research methods from one institution to the other.

With tunability in pore size, but more importantly, in pore morphology, it is anticipated that freeze-cast porous ceramics can be used as membranes for applications ranging from water purification, biomolecular separation, absorbers in biopharmaceutical manufacturing and for catalyst supports.  US and international patents have been filed for freeze-cast membranes for size-based filtration.
